paragraphs.text: %md # Oracle Machine Learning for R - Datastore and Script Repository ***Oracle Machine Learning for R*** (OML4R) makes the open source R scripting language and environment ready for the enterprise and big data. Designed for problems involving both large and small data volumes, OML4R integrates R with Oracle Autonomous Database, allowing users to run R commands and scripts for statistical, machine learning, and visualization analyses on database tables and views using R syntax. Many familiar R functions are overloaded that translate R behavior into SQL for running in-database. In this notebook, we highlight the datastore and script repository features of OML4R. With a datastore, you can store R objects in a named datastore entry. This named datastore can then be used in subsequent R sessions and even be made available to other users or programs by granting/revoking read permissions. R objects, including OML4R proxy objects, exist for the duration of the current R session unless you explicitly save them. You can save one or more R objects, including OML4R proxy objects, to a named datastore and then load those objects in a later R session. This is also useful when using embedded R execution. Datastores exist in the user’s Oracle Database schema. A datastore, and the objects it contains, persist in the database until explicitly deleted. Using a datastore, you can: * Save OML4R and other R objects in one R session and load them in another R session * Pass non-scalar arguments to R functions for use in embedded R execution from both the R, and more importantly, the SQL API where only scalar values can be passed to functions * List available datastores and explore the contents of a datastore With the script repository, users can: * Create and store user-defined R functions as scripts in Oracle Database * Grant or revoke the read/execute privilege to a script * List available scripts * Load a script function into the R environment * Drop a script from the script repository You can make scripts either private or global. A private script is available only to the owner. A global script is available to any user. For private scripts, the owner of the script may grant the read privilege to other users or revoke that privilege. Copyright (c) 2022 Oracle Corporation ###### The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0 ---

msg.data:
Oracle Machine Learning for R - Datastore and Script Repository

Oracle Machine Learning for R (OML4R) makes the open source R scripting language and environment ready for the enterprise and big data. Designed for problems involving both large and small data volumes, OML4R integrates R with Oracle Autonomous Database, allowing users to run R commands and scripts for statistical, machine learning, and visualization analyses on database tables and views using R syntax. Many familiar R functions are overloaded that translate R behavior into SQL for running in-database.

In this notebook, we highlight the datastore and script repository features of OML4R.

With a datastore, you can store R objects in a named datastore entry. This named datastore can then be used in subsequent R sessions and even be made available to other users or programs by granting/revoking read permissions.

R objects, including OML4R proxy objects, exist for the duration of the current R session unless you explicitly save them. You can save one or more R objects, including OML4R proxy objects, to a named datastore and then load those objects in a later R session. This is also useful when using embedded R execution. Datastores exist in the user’s Oracle Database schema. A datastore, and the objects it contains, persist in the database until explicitly deleted.

Using a datastore, you can:

  • Save OML4R and other R objects in one R session and load them in another R session
  • Pass non-scalar arguments to R functions for use in embedded R execution from both the R, and more importantly, the SQL API where only scalar values can be passed to functions
  • List available datastores and explore the contents of a datastore

With the script repository, users can:

  • Create and store user-defined R functions as scripts in Oracle Database
  • Grant or revoke the read/execute privilege to a script
  • List available scripts
  • Load a script function into the R environment
  • Drop a script from the script repository

You can make scripts either private or global. A private script is available only to the owner. A global script is available to any user. For private scripts, the owner of the script may grant the read privilege to other users or revoke that privilege.

Copyright (c) 2022 Oracle Corporation

The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

paragraphs.title: Import R libraries and create a data table
paragraphs.text:
%md

To use OML4R, first import the library ORE.

Users can get online help using R's help function and specifying the function of interest.

msg.data:
To use OML4R, first import the library ORE.

Users can get online help using R's help function and specifying the function of interest.

paragraphs.title: Import libraries and check RQADMIN role
paragraphs.text:
%r

library(ORE)
library(MASS)  # for Boston data set

msg.data:
Attaching package: ‘MASS’


The following object is masked from ‘package:OREstats’:

    fitdistr

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Create dataframes and load them into Autonomous Database

We load three data sets, then invoke create and display the columns for each. These will be used in exploring datastore functionality.

msg.data:
Create dataframes and load them into Autonomous Database

We load three data sets, then invoke create and display the columns for each. These will be used in exploring datastore functionality.

paragraphs.title: Create IRIS temporary database table and get proxy object
paragraphs.text:
%r

IRIS_TMP <- ore.push(iris)

z.show(colnames(IRIS_TMP))

msg.data: Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species

paragraphs.title: Create MTCARS temporary data table
paragraphs.text:
%r

MTCARS_TMP <- ore.push(mtcars)  

z.show(colnames(MTCARS_TMP))

msg.data: mpg cyl disp hp drat wt qsec vs am gear carb

paragraphs.title: Create BOSTON temporary data table
paragraphs.text:
%r

BOSTON_TMP <- ore.push(Boston)

z.show(colnames(BOSTON_TMP))

msg.data: crim zn indus chas nox rm age dis rad tax ptratio black lstat medv

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Save R objects to datastore

Save the original *iris* data set and the temporary BOSTON proxy object to a datastore named “ds_rdata”, overwriting if the named datastore already exists. Note that you can store actual data objects in a datastore, but large data objects should remain as database tables for performance and scalability.

By storing the BOSTON_TMP object, the temporary table will not be deleted when the session terminates.

msg.data:
Save R objects to datastore

Save the original iris data set and the temporary BOSTON proxy object to a datastore named “ds_rdata”, overwriting if the named datastore already exists. Note that you can store actual data objects in a datastore, but large data objects should remain as database tables for performance and scalability.

By storing the BOSTON_TMP object, the temporary table will not be deleted when the session terminates.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.save(iris, BOSTON_TMP, name="ds_rdata", description="r datasets", overwrite=TRUE)

%md

Add a third object, the temporary MTCARS proxy object, to that same datastore

msg.data: Add a third object, the temporary MTCARS proxy object, to that same datastore

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.save(MTCARS_TMP, name="ds_rdata", append=TRUE)

%md

---
Save the *IRIS_TMP* DataFrame to a new datastore, and then list the datastores. Notice we see the datastore name, the number of objects in the datastore, the size in bytes consumed, when the datastore was create/updated, and any description provided by the user. Our two datastores *ds_iris_proxy* and *ds_rdata* are present, with the latter containing three objects.

msg.data: Save the IRIS_TMP DataFrame to a new datastore, and then list the datastores. Notice we see the datastore name, the number of objects in the datastore, the size in bytes consumed, when the datastore was create/updated, and any description provided by the user. Our two datastores ds_iris_proxy and ds_rdata are present, with the latter containing three objects.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.save(IRIS_TMP, name="ds_iris_proxy", description="iris data.frame proxy object", overwrite=TRUE)

ore.datastore()

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
A data.frame: 2 x 5
datastore.nameobject.countsizecreation.datedescription
<chr><dbl><dbl><dttm><chr>
ds_iris_proxy115782022-07-29 16:18:50iris data.frame proxy object
ds_rdata 396032022-07-29 16:18:36r datasets

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Store model objects in a datastore

To illustrate storing other types of objects in datastores, we'll create regression models using base R and OML4R.

msg.data:
Store model objects in a datastore

To illustrate storing other types of objects in datastores, we'll create regression models using base R and OML4R.

paragraphs.text:
%r

regr1 <- lm(medv ~ ., data = Boston)

regr2 <- ore.odmGLM(formula = medv ~ age+crim+rm, data = BOSTON_TMP)

%md

Save objects to a datastore and allow the read privilege to be granted to them. Then grant the read privilege to all users by specifying user=None. Finally list the datastores to which the read privilege has been granted.

msg.data: Save objects to a datastore and allow the read privilege to be granted to them. Then grant the read privilege to all users by specifying user=None. Finally list the datastores to which the read privilege has been granted.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.save(regr1, regr2, name="ds_rmodel", grantable=TRUE, overwrite=TRUE)

ore.datastore()

msg.data:
A data.frame: 3 x 5
datastore.nameobject.countsizecreation.datedescription
<chr><dbl><dbl><dttm><chr>
ds_iris_proxy1 15782022-07-29 16:18:50iris data.frame proxy object
ds_rdata 3 96032022-07-29 16:18:36r datasets
ds_rmodel 21616682022-07-29 16:18:54NA

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.grant(name="ds_rmodel", type="datastore", user=NULL)

ore.datastore(type="grantable")

msg.data:
A data.frame: 1 x 5
datastore.nameobject.countsizecreation.datedescription
<chr><dbl><dbl><dttm><chr>
ds_rmodel21616682022-07-29 16:18:54NA

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Load datastore objects into memory

Load all R objects from a datastore to the global workspace and sort the result by name.

msg.data:
Load datastore objects into memory

Load all R objects from a datastore to the global workspace and sort the result by name.

paragraphs.text:
%md

Remove the objects regr1 and regr2 from the current environment prior to loading them from the datastore.

msg.data: Remove the objects regr1 and regr2 from the current environment prior to loading them from the datastore.

paragraphs.text:
%r

rm(regr1, regr2)

%r

z.show(sort(ore.load(name="ds_rdata")))

msg.data: BOSTON_TMP MTCARS_TMP iris

paragraphs.text:
%md

Load the named R object, ***regr2***, from the datastore to the current workspace, and check if 'regr2' is loaded.

msg.data: Load the named R object, regr2, from the datastore to the current workspace, and check if 'regr2' is loaded.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.load(name="ds_rmodel", list=c("regr2"))
'regr2' %in% ls()

msg.data: 'regr2'
TRUE

paragraphs.text:
%md

Load the named R object, ***regr1***, from the datastore to new environment ***e***.

msg.data: Load the named R object, regr1, from the datastore to new environment e.

paragraphs.text:
%r

e <- new.env()
ore.load(name="ds_rmodel", list=c("regr1"), envir=e)
ls(envir=e)

msg.data: 'regr1'
'regr1'

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Show datastores and other detail

msg.data: Show datastores and other detail

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.datastore(type="all")[,c("owner", "datastore.name", "object.count")]

msg.data:
A data.frame: 3 x 3
ownerdatastore.nameobject.count
<chr><chr><dbl>
OMLUSERds_iris_proxy1
OMLUSERds_rdata 3
OMLUSERds_rmodel 2

paragraphs.text:
%md

We can then show datastores to which other users have been granted the read privilege.

msg.data: We can then show datastores to which other users have been granted the read privilege.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.datastore(type="grant")

msg.data:
A data.frame: 1 x 2
datastore.namegrantee
<chr><chr>
ds_rmodelPUBLIC

paragraphs.text:
%md

Or, show datastores to which this user has been granted the read privilege (there currently are none).

msg.data: Or, show datastores to which this user has been granted the read privilege (there currently are none).

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.datastore(type="granted")

msg.data:
A data.frame: 0 x 6
ownerdatastore.nameobject.countsizecreation.datedescription
<chr><chr><dbl><dbl><dttm><chr>

paragraphs.text:
%md

Or, show datastores whose names match a pattern.

msg.data: Or, show datastores whose names match a pattern.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.datastore(pattern="rdata")[, c("datastore.name", "object.count")]

msg.data:
A data.frame: 1 x 2
datastore.nameobject.count
<chr><dbl>
ds_rdata3

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Describe contents of a datastore

Let's describe the contents of the ds_iris_proxy datastore.

msg.data:
Describe contents of a datastore

Let's describe the contents of the ds_iris_proxy datastore.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.datastoreSummary(name="ds_iris_proxy")

msg.data:
A data.frame: 1 x 6
object.nameclasssizelengthrow.countcol.count
<chr><chr><dbl><dbl><dbl><dbl>
IRIS_TMPore.frame15785NA5

paragraphs.text:
%md

## User privileges on a datastore

Revoke the read privilege from every user, and again show datastores to which read privilege has been granted. The result is empty.

msg.data:
User privileges on a datastore

Revoke the read privilege from every user, and again show datastores to which read privilege has been granted. The result is empty.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.revoke(name="ds_rmodel", type="datastore", user=NULL)

ore.datastore(type="grant")

msg.data:
A data.frame: 0 x 2
datastore.namegrantee
<chr><chr>

paragraphs.text:
%md

Grant the read privilege to the user OMLUSER2.

msg.data: Grant the read privilege to the user OMLUSER2.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.grant(name="ds_rmodel", type="datastore", user="OMLUSER2")

ore.datastore(type="grant")

msg.data:
A data.frame: 1 x 2
datastore.namegrantee
<chr><chr>
ds_rmodelOMLUSER2

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Delete datastore content

Delete some objects from the datastore. Delete a datastore. Show the existing datastores again.

msg.data:
Delete datastore content

Delete some objects from the datastore. Delete a datastore. Show the existing datastores again.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.delete(name="ds_rdata", list=c("iris", "BOSTON_TMP"))

ore.delete(name="ds_rdata")

ore.delete(name="ds_rmodel") 

ore.datastore()

msg.data:
1. 'iris'
  2. 'BOSTON_TMP'
'ds_rdata'
'ds_rmodel'

A data.frame: 1 x 5
datastore.nameobject.countsizecreation.datedescription
<chr><dbl><dbl><dttm><chr>
ds_iris_proxy115782022-07-29 16:18:50iris data.frame proxy object

paragraphs.text:
%md

# R Script Repository

To illustrate using the R Script Repository, we first define a function ***build_lm1*** that will fit a regression model. With this function, we create a script named “MyLM_function1”. OML4R stores named user-defined functions -- the scripts -- in the repository.

msg.data:
R Script Repository

To illustrate using the R Script Repository, we first define a function build_lm1 that will fit a regression model. With this function, we create a script named “MyLM_function1”. OML4R stores named user-defined functions – the scripts – in the repository.

paragraphs.title: Define function object
View function
paragraphs.text:
%r

build_lm1

msg.data:
function (dat) 
{
    regr <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ ., data = dat)
    return(regr)
}

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Create scripts in repository

Create ***MyLM_function1*** in the script repository

msg.data:
Create scripts in repository

Create MyLM_function1 in the script repository

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.scriptDrop("MyLM_function1", silent=TRUE)

ore.scriptCreate("MyLM_function1", FUN=build_lm1, overwrite=TRUE)

%md

List the scripts available only to the current user.

msg.data: List the scripts available only to the current user.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.scriptList(type="user")

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
A data.frame: 3 x 2
NAMESCRIPT
<chr><chr>
MyLM_function1function (dat) { regr <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ ., data = dat) return(regr) }
build.lmRestR function (dat) { dat$Species <- as.factor(dat$Species) mod <- lm(Petal.Length ~ ., dat) res <- summary(mod) res.list <- list(Coef = res$coefficients, R2 = res$r.squared) res.list }
group.countR function (df) { x <- aggregate(df[, "Species"], by = list(df$Species), FUN = length) names(x) <- c("SPECIES", "COUNT") return(x) }

paragraphs.text:
%md

Grant the read privilege to the ***MyLM_function1*** script to the user OMLUSER2.

msg.data: Grant the read privilege to the MyLM_function1 script to the user OMLUSER2.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.grant(name="MyLM_function1", type="rqscript", "OMLUSER2")

%md

List the scripts to which read privilege has been granted.

msg.data: List the scripts to which read privilege has been granted.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.scriptList(type="grant")

msg.data:
A data.frame: 1 x 2
NAMEGRANTEE
<chr><chr>
MyLM_function1OMLUSER2

paragraphs.text:
%md

Revoke the read privilege to the MyLM_function1 script from the user OMLUSER2.

msg.data: Revoke the read privilege to the MyLM_function1 script from the user OMLUSER2.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.revoke(name="MyLM_function1", type="rqscript", user="OMLUSER2")

%md

## Invoke function using embedded R execution

We'll use embedded R execution to invoke this function. First we get a proxy object to the IRIS table. then we use ***tableApply***, providing the proxy object and function name. We'll view the result and then pull the coefficients.

msg.data:
Invoke function using embedded R execution

We'll use embedded R execution to invoke this function. First we get a proxy object to the IRIS table. then we use tableApply, providing the proxy object and function name. We'll view the result and then pull the coefficients.

paragraphs.title: Get IRIS proxy object
paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.sync(table="IRIS_R")

IRIS <- IRIS_R

paragraphs.title: Use tableApply to provide full IRIS data set to function
paragraphs.text:
%r

res <- ore.tableApply(IRIS, FUN.NAME="MyLM_function1")

paragraphs.title: Show model coefficients
paragraphs.text:
%r

res_df <- data.frame(attribute = names(res$coefficients), coefficients = res$coefficients)

z.show(res_df)

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
attribute	coefficients
(Intercept)	2.17126629215508
Sepal.Width	0.495888938388551
Petal.Length	0.829243912234805
Petal.Width	-0.315155173326472
Speciesversicolor	-0.723561957780729
Speciesvirginica	-1.02349781449083

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Storing functions as 'global'

Let's define and save another function ***build_lm2***, but this time as global. We'll then invoke that function to build another model.

msg.data:
Storing functions as 'global'

Let's define and save another function build_lm2, but this time as global. We'll then invoke that function to build another model.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.scriptCreate("MyGlobalLM_function", FUN=build_lm2, overwrite=TRUE, global=TRUE)

%r

res <- ore.tableApply(IRIS, FUN.NAME="MyGlobalLM_function")

res

msg.data:
Call:
lm(formula = Petal.Width ~ Petal.Length, data = dat)

Coefficients:
 (Intercept)  Petal.Length  
     -0.3631        0.4158

paragraphs.text:
%md

List the scripts in the script repository available to the current user only.

msg.data: List the scripts in the script repository available to the current user only.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.scriptList()

msg.data:
A data.frame: 3 x 2
NAMESCRIPT
<chr><chr>
MyLM_function1function (dat) { regr <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ ., data = dat) return(regr) }
build.lmRestR function (dat) { dat$Species <- as.factor(dat$Species) mod <- lm(Petal.Length ~ ., dat) res <- summary(mod) res.list <- list(Coef = res$coefficients, R2 = res$r.squared) res.list }
group.countR function (df) { x <- aggregate(df[, "Species"], by = list(df$Species), FUN = length) names(x) <- c("SPECIES", "COUNT") return(x) }

paragraphs.text:
%md

List all of the scripts available to the current user.

msg.data: List all of the scripts available to the current user.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.scriptList(type='all')

msg.data:
A data.frame: 20 x 3
OWNERNAMESCRIPT
<chr><chr><chr>
OMLUSERMyLM_function1 function (dat) { regr <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ ., data = dat) return(regr) }
OMLUSERbuild.lmRestR function (dat) { dat$Species <- as.factor(dat$Species) mod <- lm(Petal.Length ~ ., dat) res <- summary(mod) res.list <- list(Coef = res$coefficients, R2 = res$r.squared) res.list }
OMLUSERgroup.countR function (df) { x <- aggregate(df[, "Species"], by = list(df$Species), FUN = length) names(x) <- c("SPECIES", "COUNT") return(x) }
RQSYS MyGlobalLM_function function (dat) { regr <- lm(Petal.Width ~ Petal.Length, data = dat) return(regr) }
RQSYS RQ$R.Version function() { v <- as.character(R.Version()) v[v == ""] <- NA_character_ data.frame(name=names(R.Version()), value=unname(v), stringsAsFactors=FALSE) }
RQSYS RQ$getRversion function() { data.frame(Version=as.character(getRversion()), stringsAsFactors=FALSE) }
RQSYS RQ$installed.packagesfunction() { data.frame(installed.packages()[,c(1L,3L,2L),drop=FALSE], stringsAsFactors=FALSE) }
RQSYS RQ$packageVersion function(pkg) { data.frame(Version=as.character(packageVersion(pkg=pkg)), stringsAsFactors=FALSE) }
RQSYS RQG$boxplot function(x, ...) { boxplot(x, ...) invisible(NULL) }
RQSYS RQG$cdplot function(x, ...) { if (NCOL(x) < 2L) stop("script RQG$cdplot requires 2 columns to produce graphic") x[[2L]] <- as.factor(x[[2L]]) cdplot(x[[1L]], x[[2L]], ...) invisible(NULL) }
RQSYS RQG$hist function(x, ...) { if (is.data.frame(x)) x <- x[[1L]] hist(x, ...) invisible(NULL) }
RQSYS RQG$matplot function(x, ...) { matplot(x, ...) invisible(NULL) }
RQSYS RQG$pairs function(x, ...) { if (NCOL(x) < 2L) stop("script RQG$pairs requires at least 2 columns to produce graphic") pairs(x, ...) invisible(NULL) }
RQSYS RQG$plot1d function(x, ...) { if (is.data.frame(x)) x <- x[[1L]] if (is.character(x)) x <- as.factor(x) plot(x, ...) invisible(NULL) }
RQSYS RQG$plot2d function(x, ...) { if (NCOL(x) < 2L) stop("script RQG$plot2d requires 2 columns to produce graphic") x <- x[1:2] if (is.character(x[[1L]])) x[[1L]] <- as.factor(x[[1L]]) if (is.character(x[[2L]])) x[[2L]] <- as.factor(x[[2L]]) plot(x[1:2], ...) invisible(NULL) }
RQSYS RQG$smoothScatter function(x, ...) { if (NCOL(x) < 2L) stop("script RQG$smoothScatter requires 2 columns to produce graphic") x <- x[1:2] if (is.character(x[[1L]])) x[[1L]] <- as.factor(x[[1L]]) if (is.character(x[[2L]])) x[[2L]] <- as.factor(x[[2L]]) smoothScatter(x[1:2], ...) invisible(NULL) }
RQSYS compute.randomMean function (index) { set.seed(index) x <- rnorm(10) res <- mean(x) res }
RQSYS compute.randomMeanR function (index) { set.seed(index) x <- rnorm(10) res <- mean(x) res }
RQSYS group.count function (dat) { res <- aggregate(dat, by = list(dat$Species), FUN = length) colnames(res)[1] <- "Species" res }
RQSYS my.predict function (dat) { ore.load(name = "ds_regr") pred = cbind(PRED = predict(regr, newdata = dat, supplemental.cols = "Sepal.Length"), dat["Sepal.Length"]) pred }

paragraphs.text:
%md

List the scripts available to all users.

msg.data: List the scripts available to all users.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.scriptList(type="global")

msg.data:
A data.frame: 5 x 2
NAMESCRIPT
<chr><chr>
MyGlobalLM_functionfunction (dat) { regr <- lm(Petal.Width ~ Petal.Length, data = dat) return(regr) }
compute.randomMean function (index) { set.seed(index) x <- rnorm(10) res <- mean(x) res }
compute.randomMeanRfunction (index) { set.seed(index) x <- rnorm(10) res <- mean(x) res }
group.count function (dat) { res <- aggregate(dat, by = list(dat$Species), FUN = length) colnames(res)[1] <- "Species" res }
my.predict function (dat) { ore.load(name = "ds_regr") pred = cbind(PRED = predict(regr, newdata = dat, supplemental.cols = "Sepal.Length"), dat["Sepal.Length"]) pred }

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Loading functions from the script repository

Load the MyLM_function1 and MyGlobalLM_function scripts, and pull the models to the local R session. Build the models on the IRIS data set and pull the coefficients.

msg.data:
Loading functions from the script repository

Load the MyLM_function1 and MyGlobalLM_function scripts, and pull the models to the local R session. Build the models on the IRIS data set and pull the coefficients.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.scriptLoad(name="MyLM_function1", newname = "MYLM")
ore.scriptLoad(name="MyGlobalLM_function", newname = "GlobalMYLM")

cat("MYLM: \n")
MYLM(iris)
cat("\n\nGlobalMYLM: \n")
GlobalMYLM(iris)

msg.data:
MYLM: 

Call:
lm(formula = Sepal.Length ~ ., data = dat)

Coefficients:
      (Intercept)        Sepal.Width       Petal.Length        Petal.Width  
           2.1713             0.4959             0.8292            -0.3152  
Speciesversicolor   Speciesvirginica  
          -0.7236            -1.0235  


GlobalMYLM: 

Call:
lm(formula = Petal.Width ~ Petal.Length, data = dat)

Coefficients:
 (Intercept)  Petal.Length  
     -0.3631        0.4158

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Drop scripts from repository

Drop one of the private scripts.

Drop the global script.

List the available scripts again.

msg.data:
Drop scripts from repository

Drop one of the private scripts.

Drop the global script.

List the available scripts again.

paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.scriptDrop("MyLM_function1")
ore.scriptDrop("MyGlobalLM_function", global=TRUE)
ore.scriptList(type="all")

msg.data:
A data.frame: 18 x 3
OWNERNAMESCRIPT
<chr><chr><chr>
OMLUSERbuild.lmRestR function (dat) { dat$Species <- as.factor(dat$Species) mod <- lm(Petal.Length ~ ., dat) res <- summary(mod) res.list <- list(Coef = res$coefficients, R2 = res$r.squared) res.list }
OMLUSERgroup.countR function (df) { x <- aggregate(df[, "Species"], by = list(df$Species), FUN = length) names(x) <- c("SPECIES", "COUNT") return(x) }
RQSYS RQ$R.Version function() { v <- as.character(R.Version()) v[v == ""] <- NA_character_ data.frame(name=names(R.Version()), value=unname(v), stringsAsFactors=FALSE) }
RQSYS RQ$getRversion function() { data.frame(Version=as.character(getRversion()), stringsAsFactors=FALSE) }
RQSYS RQ$installed.packagesfunction() { data.frame(installed.packages()[,c(1L,3L,2L),drop=FALSE], stringsAsFactors=FALSE) }
RQSYS RQ$packageVersion function(pkg) { data.frame(Version=as.character(packageVersion(pkg=pkg)), stringsAsFactors=FALSE) }
RQSYS RQG$boxplot function(x, ...) { boxplot(x, ...) invisible(NULL) }
RQSYS RQG$cdplot function(x, ...) { if (NCOL(x) < 2L) stop("script RQG$cdplot requires 2 columns to produce graphic") x[[2L]] <- as.factor(x[[2L]]) cdplot(x[[1L]], x[[2L]], ...) invisible(NULL) }
RQSYS RQG$hist function(x, ...) { if (is.data.frame(x)) x <- x[[1L]] hist(x, ...) invisible(NULL) }
RQSYS RQG$matplot function(x, ...) { matplot(x, ...) invisible(NULL) }
RQSYS RQG$pairs function(x, ...) { if (NCOL(x) < 2L) stop("script RQG$pairs requires at least 2 columns to produce graphic") pairs(x, ...) invisible(NULL) }
RQSYS RQG$plot1d function(x, ...) { if (is.data.frame(x)) x <- x[[1L]] if (is.character(x)) x <- as.factor(x) plot(x, ...) invisible(NULL) }
RQSYS RQG$plot2d function(x, ...) { if (NCOL(x) < 2L) stop("script RQG$plot2d requires 2 columns to produce graphic") x <- x[1:2] if (is.character(x[[1L]])) x[[1L]] <- as.factor(x[[1L]]) if (is.character(x[[2L]])) x[[2L]] <- as.factor(x[[2L]]) plot(x[1:2], ...) invisible(NULL) }
RQSYS RQG$smoothScatter function(x, ...) { if (NCOL(x) < 2L) stop("script RQG$smoothScatter requires 2 columns to produce graphic") x <- x[1:2] if (is.character(x[[1L]])) x[[1L]] <- as.factor(x[[1L]]) if (is.character(x[[2L]])) x[[2L]] <- as.factor(x[[2L]]) smoothScatter(x[1:2], ...) invisible(NULL) }
RQSYS compute.randomMean function (index) { set.seed(index) x <- rnorm(10) res <- mean(x) res }
RQSYS compute.randomMeanR function (index) { set.seed(index) x <- rnorm(10) res <- mean(x) res }
RQSYS group.count function (dat) { res <- aggregate(dat, by = list(dat$Species), FUN = length) colnames(res)[1] <- "Species" res }
RQSYS my.predict function (dat) { ore.load(name = "ds_regr") pred = cbind(PRED = predict(regr, newdata = dat, supplemental.cols = "Sepal.Length"), dat["Sepal.Length"]) pred }
